The people in the village were uneasy, you could see it on them, even though they mostly tried not to show anything.

This morning, just a few hours after Selma's dream, people in the village were moving as if black ice had formed on all paths, not only outside but also inside the houses, black ice in the kitchens and living rooms.
They moved as if their own bodies were completely alien to them, as if all their joints were inflamed and even the objects they handled were highly flammable.
They grumbled about their life all day long and, as far as possible, everyone else's.

Again and again they looked behind them, checking if someone might jump out with murderous intent, someone who had lost their mind and therefore had nothing significant left to lose, and they quickly looked forward again because anyone without reason could also attack head-on.
They looked up to rule out falling roof tiles, branches or heavy lampshades.
They avoided all animals, because they believed it could break out faster from them than from humans.
They circumvented the benign cows, which might lash out today, they avoided the dogs, even the very old ones that could barely stand but might still go for their throats today.
On such days, anything was possible; even doddering dachshunds could bite through your throat, after all, it wasn't any more far-fetched than an okapi.
Except for Selma's sister-in-law Elsbeth, the people in the village were mostly not superstitious.
They carefreely did all the things you're not supposed to do in superstitions:

They sat calmly under wall clocks, even though in superstition one can die from it, they slept with their heads towards the door, even though in superstition it means that one will soon be carried out through that very door feet first.
They hung laundry between Christmas and New Year's, which, as Elsbeth warned, in superstition equates to suicide or aiding and abetting murder.
They were not frightened when the screech owl called at night, when a horse in the stable broke out in heavy sweat, when a dog howled at night with its head lowered.
The train ride took fifteen minutes, there were no stops in between.
Since our first train ride, we always played the same game:
We would stand with our backs to the windows at the opposite train doors, Martin would close his eyes, I would look out the window of the train door that was behind Martin.
In the first grade, I told Martin what I saw during the trip, and Martin tried to memorize everything.

That worked out really well, so by the second school year I didn't have to list anything anymore and Martin, with his back to the window and eyes closed, could recite almost everything I saw through the fogged-up train window: "Wire factory," he said, exactly at the moment we were passing by the wire factory.

When I slept downstairs at Selma's, she would tell me bedtime stories with happy endings.
When I was younger, after the stories, I always grasped her wrist, put my thumb on her pulse and imagined that the whole world did everything to the rhythm of Selma's heartbeat.

I imagined the optician grinding lenses, Martin lifting a weight, Elsbeth trimming her hedge, the retailer stocking juice boxes, my mother stacking spruce branches, my father stamping prescriptions, and all doing so in exact sync with Selma's heartbeat.
I always reliably fell asleep to that, but now, at the age of ten, Selma thought I was too old for it.
